awd_titl_txt: Development of dielectrophoresis chromatography employing asymmetric insulating structures and electric fields
awd_abstract_narration:
A lab-on-a-chip is capable of automatically performing multiple complex chemical diagnostics in an electronic device that will easily fit on your thumb. As a lab-on-a chip manipulates an extremely small volume of fluid, it is also termed a microfluidic device. Miniaturization enables portability and accessibility, and opens the door for taking the chemical laboratory to where it is needed, be that a production line, a remote medical clinic, a sensitive environment, or real time monitoring of food and water safety.  From a technical standpoint, miniaturization leads to higher resolution and sensitivity, improved integration, lower cost, and an extremely rapid processing time. To manipulate and sort biological particles, such as cells and complex macromolecules, dielectrophoresis is one of the most common techniques, as it relies on differences in particle response to an applied electric field. Living and dead cells respond differently to a nonuniform electric field than dead cells, as do cells from different organisms.  Insulator-based dielectrophoresis adds another "knob" for particle sorting, with the placement of three-dimensional insulating structures as obstacles in the path of particle migration which "squeeze" the electric field.  Theory predicts that using asymmetric obstacles provides yet another "knob" to sort particles. This project will experimentally validate the use of asymmetric insulating structures and nonuniform electric fields to sort and isolate biological particles in a microfluidic device. 

Asymmetric insulating dielectrophoresis will induce acceleration in some biological particles, and deceleration in others, with instantaneous velocity determined by particle geometry and charge. Differences in acceleration will lead to different residence times, creating a separation that is similar to a chromatographic process, creating the first demonstration of dielectrophoretic chromatography. A combination of carefully designed insulating post geometries with customized DC-biased, low frequency AC electric signals in insulator-based dielectrophoresis will be used to screen various bioparticles of interest, with variations in size, shape, and charge. The chromatographic effect will lead to distinct interaction with the stationary phase, and differential migration of the particles through the device.  Particles will be eluted from the stationary phase as a ?peak? of concentrated particles and directed to a specific reservoir within the device for collection. This project will advance the state of the art in microfluidics by developing a new technique to sort and isolate particles. The present project will provide a premier research opportunity for undergraduate and graduate students, and will also assist in providing research opportunities for female students through the Women in Engineering programs.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Food and water safety, environmental monitoring and clinical screening are examples of fields where microfluidic devices or lab-on-a-chip systems can make a significant impact, since in these areas obtaining a rapid response is critical, particularly in analyses involving biological cells and biomarkers.

Microfluidics offers attractive advantages over traditional bench-scale techniques: only small quantities of samples and reagents are required, higher resolution and sensitivity, improved level of integration, lower cost, and much shorter processing times. Bioanalysis is one of the fields that has been most benefited with the marriage of microfluidics and analytical sciences.

Our work for this NSF award was focused on the development of an electrokinetic microfluidic technique for the separation of particle mixtures, including macromolecules, viruses, cells, and polystyrene microparticles. We developed a unique methodology where we employ electric potentials (direct current and low-frequency alternating current) as the driving force to separate, isolate and identify target particles. We exploited four distinct electrokinetic phenomena: linear electrophoresis, non-linear electrophoresis, electroosmosis, and dielectrophoresis. Briefly, we used microchannels made from polydimethylsiloxane, which we filled out with an electrolyte solution of low conductivity and introduced the mixture of particles (protein, virus, cells, microparticles, etc.) that we wanted to analyze. Then, by applying an electric potential, the electrokinetic phenomena arose exerting forces on the particles producing effective particle movement within the microchannel. Low applied electric potentials resulted in the generation of only linear electrokinetic phenomena (linear electrophoresis and electroosmosis). While increasing the magnitude of the applied potentials resulted in the additional generation of non-linear electrokinetic phenomena (dielectrophoresis and non-linear electrokinetics). These systems are highly flexible, as it is easy to fine-tune the operation of the system by simply modifying the magnitude of the applied electric field and shifting between linear and nonlinear electrokinetics.

The work performed as part of this NSF award included detailed mathematical modeling and extensive experimentation. During this work, we learned that non-linear electrophoresis (also called electrophoresis of the second kind) is a major force that influences particle movement at high electric fields. We learned how to take advantage of this phenomenon to significantly concentrate particles of interest and perform particle separations. This knowledge was used to design separations of protein nanoparticles, macrophage viruses, bacterial and yeast cells, and mixtures of polystyrene particles.  

The results from this NSF award allowed us to gain new knowledge on the fundamentals of electrokinetics and use this new knowledge to design better separation processes of particles of interest.  

  1. We identified the electrokinetic equilibrium condition, as the condition where all the electrokinetic forces exerted on a particle are in equilibrium, resulting in a net particle velocity of zero.
  2. We identified the importance of electrophoresis of the second kind
  3. We identified a methodology for assessing the electrophoresis of the second kind mobility.
  4. We separated mixtures of the following particles: protein nanoparticles, macrophage viruses, bacterial and yeast cells, and mixtures of polystyrene particles.
  5. We were able to separate almost identical microparticles employing the new knowledge generated by this grant.
  6. We used well-known and well-established chromatography parameters to numbers of plates and resolution to assess the performance of our separation processes.

The results obtained from this project advanced the field of microfluidics and electrokinetic separations. All of these research results were published in 25 peer-reviewed journal articles and numerous conference presentations. Also, the students working on this project obtained eight student awards at international conferences. 

A total of 12 students worked on this project, 9 were undergraduate and three were graduate students.  Six students were female and two students were a minority. Eight undergraduate students are now published authors of journal articles, and some of them obtained several publications from their work in this NSF award. Having a strong publication record gives them a major advantage when applying to graduate school.

Furthermore, this NSF award also enabled two distinct outreach activities:

a)       Women in Engineering:  We ran two times (08/2018 and 08/2019) the laboratory experience “Moving liquid and particles with electricity” as part of a Women in Engineering event “We’re in motion.”  The goal was to introduce these young women to engineering by showing them that there are many fields and branches of engineering. We showed them a novel area of engineering: microfluidics; which is a multi-disciplinary area.

b)      Middle School workshop: In April 2018 and March 2019 we conducted a Workshop on Microfluidics & Diffusion for middle school students (6th grade) from Rochester school 43.  In this workshop, the students made small channels from Jell-O using cast-molding techniques, very similar to what we use in our laboratory to make devices from polydimethylsiloxane.  After the channels were ready, we introduced two different dyes and the students observed the mixing of the two dyes through diffusion. They learned fundamental concepts of microfluidics, such as laminar flow, and mass transfer with Fick’s law of diffusion. 

 


Last Modified: 05/30/2022
Modified by: Blanca H Lapizco-Encinas
